newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Gevaert split alters Belgian financial landscape.
newsitem.headline: Gevaert split alters Belgian financial landscape.

text.p: A reshuffle in shares of Belgian holding companies Gevaert, Almanij and Cobepa will bring Gevaert's Flemish and German interests under control of Almanij, while Gevaert's other interests will be moved to French-owned Cobepa, the companies said on Friday.

In one of the most complex operations on the Brussels bourse in years, Flemish Gevaert-Almanij and French-owned Cobepa will each go their own way after decades of close cooperation, in a move which could profoundly change the power balance in Belgium's financial scene.
"We are separating on good terms. Each side has taken off with his favourite furniture," Gevaert Chief Executive Officer Andre Leysen said at a joint news conference.
Gevaert is now 60 percent owned by Cobepa and families which act in concert with Cobepa. The rest is owned by the public.
Trade in shares of Almanij, Gevaert, Imperial Invest and of Cobepa and affiliates Ibe l and Belvuco was suspended on the Brussels bourse on Friday.

Gevaert's assets will be divided as follows: the "new" Gevaert will keep its minority stakes in German transport group Hapag Lloyd and German real estate firm IVG, in Kredietbank Luxembourg, and in Flemish publisher VUM and telecommunications group Telenet.

Almanij (now 11.5 percent-owned by Gevaert) will acquire a majority stake in Gevaert. Almanij is the leading shareholder of Kredietbank and one of the main power brokers in Flanders, the northern, Dutch-speaking half of Belgium.
"(With Gevaert) we now acquire an...arm which will focus on merchant banking," Almanij Chairman Jan Huyghebaert said.
Cobepa, 60 percent-owned by French Paribas, will get Gevaert's minority stakes in Swiss holding company Pargesa, Gevaert's shares in Paribas Bank Belgium, and a minority stake in retailer GIB.
Gevaert's minority stakes in German chemical group Bayer and Dutch insurer Aegon will be split more or less evenly between Cobepa and the new Gevaert.
The planned reshuffle will proceed via a series of capital operations between September 15 and November 15.
Before September, Almanij shares (which closed at 15,425 on Thursday) will be split in 10 new shares for one old share and shareholders will receive one free share per 50 split shares.

After shareholders in the three companies approve the operations at extraordinary meetings in September, Gevaert shareholders will receive for each old Gevaert share one new Gevaert share which can be exchanged into a split Almanij share.
Gevaert shareholders will also receive one Cobepa share which can be exchanged against an Almanij share.
